Hi Ken, 

By playing with the random distributions I meant instead of using=
 
uniform distribution during the transformation of the CPPN image, 
anothe=
r distribution can be used. For example if I change the 
distribution to no=
rmal (gaussian), then points that are far from 
(0,0) in space are visited =
rarely. This makes the bodies more dense 
in the center. It was just a sugg=
estion, it is not really important 
thing to consider. 

Peter

--- In neat=
@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> > 
> > * if w=
e have (x / distance), (y / distance), (distance) as input 
to 
> > the CPP=
N instead of (x) and (y), the effect is beautiful 
rotational 
> > patterns=
! Spirals and all kind of stuff come up too. So this is 
how to 
> > get ro=
tation! Just add these to the regular (x,y,1) inputs. 
> > 
> 
> That is in=
teresting, I had not thought of that.  It would be
> interesting to look at=
 patterns generated by such a CPPN.
> 
> > * Playing around with the random=
 distributions is a good idea. 
They 
> > actually control how the raw CPPN=
 pattern is about to be 
interpreted.

ng around with random distributions?  I
